title: SB 1.17.25 | Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 08-03-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 25th verse of the 7th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita. The 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with invocatory prayers and an introduction to the 25th verse of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on the punishment and reward of Kali.

segments.key_quote: You are now standing on one leg only which is your truthfulness and you are somehow or other hobbling along but quarrel personified Kali flourishing by deceit is also trying to destroy that leg.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of the verse, describing Dharma standing on one leg (truthfulness) and Kali's attempt to destroy it through deceit.

segments.key_quote: Earlier it was described Dharma which in Satya Yuga was standing on four legs, four pillars austerity, cleanliness, mercy and truthfulness.
segments.summary: The lecture details the decline of Dharma through the Yugas, from four legs in Satya Yuga to one in Kali Yuga, emphasizing that true Dharma comes from God and the Parampara system.

segments.key_quote: So real religion means there are four primary regulative observances what are they austerity cleanliness mercy and truthfulness
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts real religion with man-made religion, highlighting the four regulative principles: austerity, cleanliness, mercy, and truthfulness.

segments.key_quote: Austerity means to accept voluntarily things which may be not very comfortable for the body but are conducive for spiritual realization
segments.summary: The lecture explains austerity as voluntarily accepting inconvenience for spiritual realization, using fasting as an example and distinguishing it from fasting for other purposes, which is condemned in the Bhagavad Gita.

segments.key_quote: Similarly cleanliness is necessary both for the mind and the body simply bodily cleanliness may help to some extent people know about bodily cleanliness external cleanliness but more important is cleansing the mind
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of both bodily and mental cleanliness, stating that mental cleanliness is achieved through glorifying the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: For some people cutting the throat of a cow it doesn't matter as long as you're nice to all other fellow human beings because they believe cows don't have soul
segments.summary: The lecture criticizes a godless civilization and uses the example of cow slaughter to illustrate the lack of mercy and the consequences of ignoring God's laws.

segments.key_quote: Everyone is anxious for peace of mind but how can they get this peace of mind without cleansing the mind
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the lack of peace of mind in Kali Yuga due to the decline of austerity, cleanliness, mercy, and truthfulness, contrasting it with the peace of Sathya Yuga.

segments.key_quote: So much of untruthfulness so because of that that last leg truthfulness of Dharma is diminishing
segments.summary: The lecture uses the analogy of airline tickets and online fraud to illustrate the increasing untruthfulness in Kali Yuga and its impact on Dharma.

segments.key_quote: By too much lying propaganda truthfulness is spoilt
segments.summary: The speaker explains how pride spoils austerity, affection spoils cleanliness, intoxication spoils mercy, and lying propaganda spoils truthfulness.

segments.key_quote: The revival of bhagavata dharma can save civilization from falling prey to evils of all description
segments.summary: The lecture concludes by emphasizing the prevalence of lying propaganda and the importance of reviving Bhagavata Dharma to save civilization by following the four principles for spiritual realization.
